Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee protection but were denied by the RPD and RAD. They sought judicial review citing bias and improper standard of review.
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied a deferential standard of review instead of a complete review, contrary to its appellate role.
Credibility_Assessment: RAD applied a deferential standard to the RPD's credibility assessment, failing to conduct an independent review.
Decision_Outcome: RPD and RAD initially denied the refugee protection claim.
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed in part.
Remedy_Sought: Remand to a differently constituted RAD panel for redetermination.
Standard_of_Review: RAD must conduct a complete review of fact, law, and mixed fact and law; not merely apply reasonableness standard.
Decision_Rationale: RAD failed to fulfill its statutory duty to fully review factual and legal issues; remanded for proper appellate review.
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board - Refugee Appeal Division (IRB-RAD)

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in applying a reasonableness standard to review the RPD's decision
Governing_Law: RAD decisions on the standard of review are assessed on correctness
Evidence_Assessment: Key findings were not solely based on applicant testimony
Decision_Outcome: RAD's decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant bears burden to establish refugee claim
Credibility_Factor: RPD found applicant non-credible, credibility was critical
Legal_Rule: RPD decisions require independent review unless credibility is critical
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied incorrectly; correctness standard required for RAD's review
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; referred back for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant testimony, other evidence beyond testimony
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Federal Court Rules
Defendant_Response: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility finding
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of RAD decision, referral for re-determination
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, decision remanded to new RAD panel
Legal_Provision: Section 74 of IRPA, Standard of Review doctrine

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F(b) of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nwobi convicted of cocaine trafficking in Germany and claimed refugee status in Canada; Board failed to consider mosque arson
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board misinterpreted drug laws and failed to consider all exclusion grounds
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of Canadian law to foreign conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, details of mosque burning
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess seriousness of mosque arson
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of seriousness for crimes punishable by 10+ years
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Legal error in assessing seriousness and failure to consider arson

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee eligibility based on criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether cocaine trafficking is a serious non-political crime
Crimes.Governing_Law: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, Article 1F(b) of Refugee Convention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board improperly considered another person's sentence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Presumption of seriousness for offenses punishable by 10+ years
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign criminal record, legal submissions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Annulment and referral for new hearing

Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Potentially high due to intent and target
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Claimant's admission, contextual reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admission consistent with claim

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making a misrepresentation to obtain immigration benefits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim found to be economically motivated, not based on credible fear of persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Economic motivation outweighed claims of persecution
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation through omission or false emphasis
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to remain permanently despite claims of fear
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Crime_Name: False statements in an immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interference of persuasive Board decisions with member's discretion
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible fear; inconsistent intent to return to Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent statements about return to Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: False statements regarding intent and fear of return
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Credibility assessment based on consistency and plausibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of implausible claims and return intentions
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for credibility findings

Application_Facts: Mr. Ryivuze held a high-ranking position in Burundi's government, knew about its crimes, and did not disassociate. His role contributed to government operations despite knowledge of atrocities.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Used: Position in government, knowledge of crimes, failure to disassociate
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to believe standard, lower than civil or criminal law
Decision_Rationale: Mr. Ryivuze was complicit by association due to his role, knowledge, and failure to disengage from a regime committing crimes against humanity

Legal_Issue: Concealment of identity as a Burundian civil servant in refugee application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Evidence_Type: Documentary and circumstantial evidence of government affiliation
Basis_of_Claim: Exclusion due to misrepresentation and complicity
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Voluntary association with government committing atrocities and concealment of identity
Legal_Standard: Lower standard than civil or criminal law
Application_Factor: High-ranking government role, knowledge, lack of disassociation
Document_Fraud: Concealment of identity as a civil servant

Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (indirectly applicable)
Application_Facts: Antonio Leon Davila claimed persecution in Mexico; did not file formal charges; attempted informal means to seek protection
Residency_Compliance: Claimant sought protection in Canada; status pending at time of review
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient analysis by the original Board; lack of thorough assessment of state protection efforts
Evidence_Used: Claimant's testimony, attempts to seek help in Mexico, country condition reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide clear and convincing evidence that Mexican authorities were unable or unwilling to protect
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on sufficiency of evidence and legal application
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a differently constituted Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimant must provide clear and convincing evidence that state is unable or unwilling to protect
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to adequately analyze whether Mexico’s democratic institutions translated into effective protection; insufficient reasoning on state protection issue
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Violation_Type: Failure to meet legal standards in risk assessment
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution risks due to ethnicity and past experiences in Sri Lanka, including detention and torture; Officer reviewed country conditions and personal history
Procedural_Issue: Alleged misapplication of legal standards and failure to consider relevant evidence
Evidence_Used: Past detention records, torture claims, country condition reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient objective evidence to support new risks upon return
Outcome: Application dismissed, no reviewable error found
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was consistent with evidence and prior decisions; no reviewable error identified

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada but provided inconsistent statements and insufficient documentation regarding family residence, vehicle registration, and employment
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement within four-year period
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent statements and lack of credible evidence suggesting potential misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Applicant's statements, lack of vehicle registration, lack of employment records
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient and inconsistent evidence to prove residency
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found applicant's evidence not credible or convincing
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed without costs
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Decision_Rationale: Judge's conclusion was based on credible evidence and fell within acceptable range of outcomes due to applicant's failure to provide convincing proof of residency

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-97
Application_Facts: Mr. Balendra claimed refugee status due to persecution of northern Tamils in Sri Lanka
Residency_Compliance: Lawful temporary resident at time of claim
Procedural_Issue: CRDD failed to analyze documentary evidence of country conditions
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, documents on persecution of northern Tamils in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD did not assess significant documentary evidence regarding systemic persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility concerns raised but not determinative due to lack of evidence analysis
Remedy_Sought: Remittal for reconsideration by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: CRDD must consider all relevant evidence, including country documentation, even if credibility doubts exist

Application_Facts: Russian citizen's visa application denied due to concerns over interpreter qualifications during interview; interpreter was non-certified embassy employee
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Transcript or record of visa interview
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of actual translation errors
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of inadequate interpretation not substantiated
Outcome: Certified question on interpreter qualifications referred to Court of Appeal
Decision_Rationale: No objective evidence of bias or translation deficiency
Failure to raise issue during interview undermines claim
No impact on fairness of process established
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after the expiration of their authorized stay; pending applications and personal relationships cited as reasons to defer removal.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant with rejected permanent residence and risk assessment applications
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal filed after final removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over stay applications
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Pending immigration applications, family ties in Canada, claimed risks in Peru
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Claims were vague, speculative, and unsupported by evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to lack of substantiated evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian and compelling circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious question, irreparable harm, or favorable balance of convenience demonstrated

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought to delay removal citing family separation, inadequate care for dependents, and fear of assailants in Peru.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to a final removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review and stay application following administrative rejections
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's authority to grant stays under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, health concerns, safety risks upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assertions not supported by concrete evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on special circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest favors enforcement; no irreparable harm shown

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate application refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C consideration and stay of removal
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-refusal judicial review and stay application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of family ties, integration, and risks in country of return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application and stay motion both denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C considerations require compelling grounds beyond normal immigration rules
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Family separation, best interests of child, risk in Peru
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending applications, spousal relationship, perceived risks
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Sections 25(1) IRPA for H&C, Section 48 for removal
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Canada Border Services Agency upheld removal order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, medical reports, police records (if any)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Pre-removal risk assessment refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 and Section 107-113 of IRPA (PRRA provisions)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of harm if returned to Peru; previous refugee claim and H&C applications rejected.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Inadmissible foreign national with prior negative determinations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA conducted post-rejection; appeal via stay motion
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of PRRA outcome
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged threats from assailants, lack of state protection, family vulnerability
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence; claims previously assessed and dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to inconsistency and lack of proof
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on risk claims
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No new evidence of risk; public interest supports removal
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Immigration Division

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration-related offences under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection due to a blood feud but was deemed not credible by the Board.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: The Board failed to inform the applicant of concerns, violating procedural fairness.
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not adequately address corroborating certificates or country conditions.
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings made without sufficient justification; based on speculation rather than evidence.
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Total evidence rule, need for clear justification of credibility findings
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for factual issues, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Speculative plausibility assessments without addressing supporting evidence; lack of procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using forged documents for the purpose of deception
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in making adverse credibility findings based on unsupported facts and implausibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings made without adequate analysis of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection due to blood feud in Albania
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false passport and credibility of claim
Crimes.Application_Error: Board dismissed corroborating certificates without adequate reasoning
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Speculative plausibility assessments contrary to total evidence rule
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Decisions must be based on total evidence and justified clearly
Crimes.Application_Factor: Entry into Canada with a false passport
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for factual issues, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False passport used to enter Canada

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nguyen, a Vietnamese citizen, had a nine-month absence from his Vietnamese business and expressed intent to stay in Canada with his children.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for a work permit
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to prove compliance with temporary residency requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's ties to Vietnam, duration of absence from business, statements about family in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of strong evidence showing intent to return to Vietnam
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen's claim of intent to return was weakened by prolonged absence and desire to remain with children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and grant work permit
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Proof of intention to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Tribunal reasonably concluded Nguyen did not prove he would leave Canada after his authorized stay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer acted reasonably in refusing the work permit due to insufficient proof of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Regulation 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; work permit not issued
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen lacked strong ties to Vietnam and expressed desire to stay in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Business ownership in Vietnam, duration of absence, familial connections in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 200(1)(b) – Requirement to prove intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant failed to meet regulatory requirement to demonstrate intent to depart Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Weak ties to home country and expressed intent to remain in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of applicant’s intent based on ties to home country
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration of absence from Vietnamese business and presence of children in Canada
Crimes.Authority: Canadian Visa Office, Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution by wife's family in Pakistan; inconsistencies in testimony; lack of subjective fear; existence of internal flight alternative in Rawalpindi or Kasur
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Overemphasis on lack of corroborative documents
Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistencies in testimony
Concluded lack of subjective fear
Unreasonable credibility findings
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification question
Relief_Sought: Certification of a question of law
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of credibility, plausibility, and internal flight alternative assessments
Decision_Rationale: Despite errors in credibility assessment, valid internal flight alternative supports conclusion that applicants are not Convention refugees

Application_Facts: Applicants were denied citizenship due to insufficient physical presence; applicants were abroad during assessment period
Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to review residency questionnaires; lack of fair hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not consider submitted questionnaires
Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a different citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) residency requirement; principles of procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Applicants failed to meet residency requirement; judge erred in not providing fair opportunity to present case
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court Trial Division

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration violation under paragraph 27(2)(h) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Removal in conflict with judicial order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was removed despite a court order requiring his presence for a criminal hearing.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Removal executed without regard to conflicting judicial order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 50(1) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal violated s. 50(1) as it conflicted with a judicial order requiring the applicant’s presence.

Crimes.Violation_Type: Execution of removal order conflicting with judicial requirement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant removed despite court order requiring attendance at criminal proceeding; later returned voluntarily.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to comply with s. 50(1) before removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Judicial order mandating presence for criminal hearing
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Declaration addressing consequences of unlawful removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Compliance with s. 50(1) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal contravened statutory prohibition under s. 50(1); declaration warranted despite voluntary return.

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Lawfulness of removal during pending criminal proceedings
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Removal without ensuring compliance with judicial requirements
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Violation of s. 50(1) due to conflict with judicial order
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to ensure presence required by court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with voluntary departure orders
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visitor status, applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds, had minor child Min Ji under 18 at time of application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants without valid status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and failed to depart voluntarily
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Inadequate consideration of H&C factors, particularly best interests of the child
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Establishment in Canada, family ties, children’s integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer underestimated hardships and dismissed establishment in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and re-assessment of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to properly assess best interests of Min Ji rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness and incorrect application of H&C tests, including best interests of the child
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case returned for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not found to be an issue
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residential history, employment records, children’s education in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to long-term residence and family establishment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of minor child Min Ji
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately analyze best interests of the child and disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Extent of applicants’ establishment in Canada and impact on children
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to officer’s decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long-term illegal stay since 2001, unauthorized work, integration of children

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered as visitors, remained since 2001, established lives, applied for permanent residence on H&C grounds
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visas and remained without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient analysis of best interests of Min Ji, who was under 18 at time of application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, community ties, children’s education and integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer inadequately assessed hardships and best interests of the child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and re-determination with proper H&C assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable failure to consider Min Ji's best interests

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Convention refugee status based on past persecution in Chile; Tribunal accepted credible evidence of past persecution but dismissed claim due to changed country conditions without addressing s. 2(3)
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to consider s. 2(3) despite evidence of past persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess compelling reasons arising from past persecution under s. 2(3)
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant's evidence was found credible
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed based on changed country conditions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act regarding continued refugee status despite changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Tribunal erred in law by not considering s. 2(3) which requires assessment of compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Violation_Type: Failure to provide adequate state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, 97
Application_Facts: Ms. Myle experienced domestic violence in St. Vincent and fears persecution due to lack of effective state protection
Procedural_Issue: RPD dismissed claim twice without adequately addressing updated country evidence or credibility of testimony
Evidence_Used: Information on shelters and police response in St. Vincent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD relied on outdated or incomplete country information
Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Myle's testimony found credible by reviewing court
RPD's negative credibility finding deemed unreasonable
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of harm due to failure of state protection
Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to consider current evidence on domestic violence and state protection in St. Vincent
Shelter operations and police effectiveness were not properly assessed

Application_Facts: Family’s Shia Muslim identity and Iranian descent in Bahrain; risk of religious persecution and family separation if returned to Bahrain or Iran
Procedural_Issue: Failure to assess risks related to religion and ethnicity; lack of procedural fairness in the Board's assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of persecution cited by the Board; failure to consider relevant risk factors
Decision_Outcome: Refugee protection claim rejected by the Board
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review; decision overturned
Remedy_Sought: Re-evaluation of refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of persecution based on ethnicity, religion, and family unity under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to properly assess the risks associated with the family’s Shia Muslim identity and Iranian background in Bahrain

Legal_Issue: Were the Board's credibility and state protection findings reasonable?
Outcome: Decision unreasonable due to flawed credibility analysis and insufficient consideration of gender guidelines
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant’s credibility based on implausible assumptions about domestic abuse, ignored context of gender-related persecution
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Flawed credibility analysis, inadequate consideration of gender guidelines
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review application filed in Federal Court
Application_Error: Presumed state protection without sufficient basis
Legal_Standard: Credibility and state protection assessments must be reasonable

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant used a fraudulent Israeli passport to flee domestic abuse in Georgia
Evidence_Used: Details omitted in testimony, improvements in Georgia's handling of domestic abuse
Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to implausibility of abuse and omissions
Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable, case referred back
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable assessment of credibility and state protection
Decision_Rationale: Inadequate consideration of gender-related persecution guidelines

Aggravating_Factors: Lack of effective state protection, cultural barriers
Risk_Nature: Systemic failure to protect women from domestic violence
Targeted_Victimization: Women subjected to domestic abuse in Georgia
Evidence_Credibility: Undermined by Board based on implausible assumptions
Credibility_Assessment: Flawed due to lack of gender-sensitive analysis

Application_Facts: Applicant obtained documents through deception to escape domestic abuse
Evidence_Used: Nature of abuse, circumstances of flight
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonably questioned based on implausible assumptions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness in credibility and protection assessments
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Failure to apply gender-specific guidelines and proper credibility analysis

Application_Facts: Parmar applied as an assisted relative with a job offer but was rejected due to insufficient points, lack of relevant experience, and concerns about personal suitability.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated by Parmar to challenge the visa officer's decision
Evidence_Used: Job offer, application documents, assessment of points for SVP, occupational demand, and personal suitability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient points, lack of relevant experience, concerns about personal suitability
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility or suitability assessment by visa officer
Relief_Sought: Overturning of visa officer's rejection decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to reverse the refusal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment under Immigration Act and Regulations including point system and personal suitability
Decision_Rationale: The visa officer did not err in assessing that Parmar failed to meet the required points and qualifications; Federal Court found no error in the decision

Application_Facts: Applicants sought judicial review of a denied deferral of removal to Costa Rica.
Procedural_Issue: The officer failed to analyze conflicting medical evidence and did not provide applicants an opportunity to respond.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to analyze conflicting medical evidence, lack of opportunity for applicants to respond
Decision_Outcome: Removal officer's decision to deny deferral of removal
Outcome: Court set aside the officer's decision and remitted the case for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review, reconsideration of removal decision
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable due to failure to assess conflicting medical evidence and procedural fairness

Application_Facts: Officer dismissed letters as inconsistent with documentary evidence but used them to undermine the Applicant's claim; no conflicting evidence challenged Amnesty International reports.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent use of letters; lack of contradictory evidence against credible reports
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable assessment of applicant's credibility
Remedy_Sought: Remittal for reassessment by another officer
Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable handling of evidence and failure to provide oral hearing

Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and determination of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony found inconsistent, implausible, and contradictory
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence from U.S. and Canadian claims
Basis_of_Claim: Religious persecution as a Coptic Christian in Egypt
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of corroboration for key events, discrepancies between U.S. and Canadian claims
Application_Error: One minor error acknowledged but not determinative
Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness in credibility and weight of evidence
Application_Factor: Consistency of testimony, availability of corroborating evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment based on inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD reasonably questioned credibility due to omissions, inconsistent travel details, questionable military documents, and delayed asylum claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish activism and draft evasion
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing and plausibility of asylum claim
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicious military documents lacking official features

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada illegally and claimed asylum after detentions in Turkey
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues related to threats, travel, and documentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over RPD decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration for key events
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies affecting reliability

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to immigration officials
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Truthfulness of applicant’s statements in asylum application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Multiple inconsistencies in testimony and forms; minor errors but overall reasonable finding
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to Kurdish activism and draft evasion
Application_Error: Inconsistent statements about travel and threats
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative law

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility of draft evasion as basis for persecution claim
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Letters on draft evasion lacked security features and were deemed suspicious
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish risk of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony and questionable documents
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to draft evasion and Kurdish activism
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to credibility issues
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed fear of imprisonment and persecution in Turkey

Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant meets the residency requirement under section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Type: Duration of physical presence in Canada, family ties, vacation patterns, overseas employment
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant’s failure to reside in Canada for at least three out of four years prior to application
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Prolonged absence from Canada due to long-term overseas employment, failing the 'centralized mode of existence' test
Decision_Maker: Citizenship judge (initial), Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (appellant)
Application_Error: Misrepresentation of residency status or failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Assessment_Standard: One day counted for each day physically present in Canada as a permanent resident
Legal_Standard: Three out of four years residency requirement
Application_Factor: Time spent in Canada (22 days), maintenance of family ties, vacation visits
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship judge's decision overturned, application denied
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by appeal context)

Risk_Assessment: High risk of continued threats if returned to Mexico City
Credibility_Assessment: Positive credibility given by court, but inadequately considered by IRB Member
Legal_Provision: Canadian refugee law – burden of proof on balance of probabilities

Aggravating_Factors: Occurred in context of domestic violence
Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-victimization in Mexico City
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony found credible; IRB failed to adequately assess

Aggravating_Factors: Lack of familial support in Mexico City
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to lack of protection and support in Mexico City
Credibility_Assessment: Credible testimony ignored or underweighted by IRB
Legal_Provision: Canadian refugee law – burden of proof on balance of probabilities

Aggravating_Factors: Continued harassment after relocation within Mexico
Fear of being tracked in Mexico City
Risk_Assessment: High risk of continued stalking and harassment in Mexico City
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility established; IRB failed to engage with evidence
Legal_Provision: Canadian refugee law – burden of proof on balance of probabilities

Legal_Issue: Whether the Band Council Resolution is ultra vires
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants failed to demonstrate irreparable harm
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants did not meet burden of proving irreparable harm or favorable balance of convenience
Legal_Rule: Court must determine if resolution exceeds authority of Band Council and whether interim injunction is warranted
Standard_of_Review: Balance of convenience and irreparable harm standard
Grounds_for_Claim: Ultra vires action by Band Council
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; motion dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Availability of internal appeal processes, proximity to full election in 2010
Legal_Framework: Federal Court review of First Nations governance actions
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of Band Council Resolution, procedural rules
Outcome: Motion dismissed; costs awarded against Applicants

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading statements in tax returns
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed ignorance and reliance on third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of misunderstanding not deemed credible or sufficient
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) allows waiver only under extraordinary circumstances beyond taxpayer's control
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for waiver of penalties and interest due to alleged misunderstanding
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of compliance history, lack of due diligence, no evidence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Framework: ITA and CRA policy guidelines (e.g., IC 92-2)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied request based on absence of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and declarative evidence regarding tax remittance practices
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Waiver of penalties and interest under ITA Subsection 220(3.1)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet statutory payroll obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to remit CPP contributions, citing ignorance and third-party advice
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Taxpayer/employer subject to payroll deduction requirements
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Reliance on third-party advice without verification
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of extraordinary circumstances or due diligence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims not considered credible or sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ignorance of law and third-party errors do not constitute extraordinary circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to withhold Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant cited ignorance and third-party advice; CRA found no extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show undue hardship or extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's misunderstanding not accepted as valid defense
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Waiver allowed only under extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for relief based on claimed ignorance and reliance on advisor
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Compliance history, due diligence, nature of error
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA maintained denial due to lack of qualifying circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Administrative records and taxpayer submissions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to remit Canada Pension Plan contributions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in denying relief under Subsection 220(3.1) of the ITA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to remit, paid penalties, claimed ignorance and third-party error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to demonstrate eligibility for relief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of misunderstanding not supported by evidence of due diligence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 220(3.1) requires extraordinary circumstances or hardship for relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for waiver due to non-compliance from misinterpretation of obligations
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Payment history, compliance record, explanation for failure
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied request citing lack of extraordinary circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, correspondence, application materials

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that the Applicant was not a convention refugee or person in need of protection
Evidence_Type: Alleged past bullying, ethnic tensions in Guyana
Basis_of_Claim: Past bullying and ethnic tensions in Guyana

Legal_Standard: Convention refugee definition; Person in need of protection
Application_Factor: Personalized risk vs. general country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Upheld Board's rejection of refugee claim

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; new hearing ordered before a different panel

State_Protection_Assessment: Insufficient state protection in China for members of unregistered churches
Risk_Factor: Persecution by Public Security Bureau (PSB), inconsistent enforcement, fear of detention or punishment
Credibility: Testimony found plausible despite some inconsistencies
State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate due to risk of persecution for practicing religion outside state-sanctioned channels
Risk_Nature: Non-state sanctioned religious practice leading to potential detention, surveillance, or harassment
Victim_Basis: Religious belief and participation in an unregistered church

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Validity of information demand during criminal investigation vs. audit
Crimes.Governing_Law: Income Tax Act, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (s. 11(c))
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Nature and purpose of MNR's questionnaire and inter-divisional coordination
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mixed success; further cross-examination and document production ordered
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayers to show predominant purpose shifted to penal liability
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Blurred lines between Audit and Investigations divisions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under Jarvis, inspection powers cannot be used once purpose shifts to penal liability
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not finally determined; remitted for further factual inquiry
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Questionnaire sent by MNR indicating criminal investigation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Distinction between audit and investigation under tax administration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: MNR asserted authority under audit provisions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence of agency conduct
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Declaration of unlawfulness and prohibition of enforcement actions
Crimes.Outcome: Re-attendance for cross-examination and production of documents ordered
Crimes.Legal_Provision: ITA sections related to information demands and inspection powers
Crimes.Authority: Jarvis precedent on separation of audit and investigation functions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Lawfulness of information demand during potential criminal investigation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (s. 11(c)), Income Tax Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Content of MNR letter and interaction between audit and investigation units
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Partially invalid; further inquiry required on predominant purpose
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayers to demonstrate adversarial relationship crystallized
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Indications in correspondence suggesting criminal focus
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Jarvis rule requiring warrant-based process when penal purpose dominates
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of self-incrimination under guise of audit
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not finally decided; remanded for further examination
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Letter from MNR implying investigation into taxpayer conduct
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative vs. criminal procedures in tax enforcement
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CCRA maintained use of audit tools was lawful
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official correspondence and internal coordination records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Declaration of illegality and injunction against enforcement
Crimes.Outcome: Order for re-attendance and document production
Crimes.Authority: Jarvis precedent limiting audit powers during criminal probes

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to legality of information request during investigation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Validity of information demand under ITA amid ongoing criminal investigation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Income Tax Act, Charter of Rights (s. 11(c))
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Ambiguity in MNR letter regarding investigation status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to prove shift in investigative purpose
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure of MNR to clarify non-investigative status
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Jarvis principle: inspection powers inapplicable when penal purpose prevails
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Exposure to self-incrimination through compelled disclosure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Demand letters related to tax loss arrangements
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Framework distinguishing compliance audits from criminal probes
Crimes.Defendant_Response: MNR relied on statutory audit authority
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written demands and taxpayer filings
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Invalidation of demand and restraint on enforcement
Crimes.Legal_Provision: ITA sections permitting information collection during audits
Crimes.Authority: Jarvis decision governing limits on audit powers

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection exclusion based on alleged complicity in international crimes
Legal_Provision_Involved: Rule of 'personal and knowing participation' in complicity; 'reasonable grounds to believe' standard
Outcome: Applicant excluded from refugee protection due to reasonable grounds for belief in complicity
Grounds_for_Claim: Voluntary 16-year service in Sri Lankan army, participation in combat operations, mapping cordon and search missions, awareness of atrocities, failure to disengage despite opportunities
Legal_Framework: International law on crimes against humanity, principles of complicity, Canadian immigration and refugee law

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection exclusion based on potential involvement in crimes against humanity
Legal_Provision_Involved: Standard of 'reasonable grounds to believe'; requirement of personal and knowing participation or toleration
Outcome: Board's determination upheld; judicial review dismissed
Grounds_for_Claim: Extended military service, direct operational role, knowledge of atrocities, renewal of service, trusted position within military
Legal_Framework: International criminal law, jurisprudence on complicity, Canadian Refugee Protection Division procedures

Legal_Issue: Was the Refugee Protection Division's decision to reject the applicant's refugee claim based on credibility justified?
Evidence_Assessment: Minor errors in spelling, document routing, and date inconsistencies were considered; key evidence was ignored or misinterpreted; explanations and contextual factors such as Gender Guidelines were not adequately considered.
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected the applicant's refugee claim based on credibility concerns
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish credibility and well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in documentation, lack of contextual analysis, failure to consider explanations
Legal_Rule: The standard of review for credibility findings is reasonableness with deference to the RPD; decisions must be based on reasoned analysis and context
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable credibility assessment by the RPD
Outcome_on_Merits: The court found the RPD's decision lacked justification and was unreasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Spelling errors, document routing discrepancies, date inconsistencies, applicant's explanations, Gender Guidelines
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Federal Court Rules
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal testimony, policy guidelines (Gender Guidelines)
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, quashing of RPD decision, remand for new hearing
Outcome: Court granted judicial review, quashed the RPD decision, and remanded for a new determination by a different panel
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (jurisdiction of Federal Court), principles of procedural fairness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant made false statements or misrepresented facts in immigration application

Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 17 of Immigration Rules, principles of natural justice
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of whether omitted documents suggest bias

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Transparency and completeness of tribunal record
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A reasonable person would perceive bias if process appears unfair
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal questions, reasonableness for factual findings

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer claims only relevant documents were considered

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Allegation of unfair process in immigration decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant was denied fair opportunity to respond

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Review of which documents should have been disclosed

Crimes.Legal_Rule: All relevant documents must be included in CTR

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Only decision-influencing documents required in CTR
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Internal government records, affidavits

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 68(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ferri, a permanent resident, was convicted of a narcotics offense, triggering automatic cancellation of his deportation stay under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Constitutional challenge to s. 68(4) raised during appeal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record, IRPA provisions, Charter arguments
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacks jurisdiction to consider constitutionality of s. 68(4)
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation and hearing of constitutional challenge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of IRPA sections 162(1) and 68(4)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Explicit statutory language of s. 68(4) limits IAD’s role to factual determinations, overriding general jurisdiction under s. 162(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Deportation order under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutionality of deportation provisions in immigration law
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld due to lack of IAD jurisdiction over constitutional issues
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Charter rights due to denial of appeal rights after second serious offense
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Cancellation of deportation stay and termination of appeal
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent resident seeking protection from deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of heroin for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of IAD to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4) IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Code of Canada, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal before IAD and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for possession of heroin for trafficking used as basis for deportation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed constitutional challenge; Federal Court upheld decision
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate IAD jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 68(4) IRPA removes IAD's ability to stay deportation upon second serious offense
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Charter challenge to s. 68(4) IRPA based on fairness and right to appeal
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Constitutional challenge not heard; deportation process resumed
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Ferri argued that s. 68(4) violates Charter rights
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal conviction documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation and constitutional review by IAD
Crimes.Outcome: Remedy denied due to statutory bar on IAD jurisdiction

Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge's decision met the legal residence requirements under the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Appeal allowed; original decision overturned and referred back for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: Abdallah provided vague and incomplete evidence of physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Type: Residency documentation, addresses, proof of presence
Legal_Provision: Requirement to reside in Canada for at least 1095 days in the four years preceding application
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies and ambiguities in submitted documents, including mismatched addresses and lack of proof for certain periods
Application_Error: Failure to meet residency requirement and provide complete evidence
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the citizenship judge's decision
Evidence_Ignored: Inconsistencies in addresses and gaps in residency proof
Legal_Standard: Permanent resident must be physically present in Canada for 1095 days within four years prior to application
Application_Factor: Physical presence and documented residency in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside and referred to another citizenship judge
Document_Fraud: Mismatched addresses and incomplete documentation suggesting potential misrepresentation

Legal_Issue: Standard of Review in Credibility Assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible by RPD

Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection claim, Administrative review, Judicial review
Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court
Application_Error: Alleged incorrect standard of review applied by RAD
Application_Factor: Credibility, Basis of fear, Country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, Appeal dismissed, Judicial review dismissed
